title: 105_hr1918
content: The Act may be cited as the "Reno, Nevada, Railroad Right-of-Way Conveyance Validation Act" and validates conveyances. SEC. 2 validates conveyances concerning lands in Washoe County, Nevada, part of the right-of-way granted to the Central Pacific Railway Company in 1862. SEC. 3 specifies the conveyances of lands in Washoe County. The conveyances of land in Washoe County, Nevada, validated in section 2, include transactions between Charles Crocker and various grantees recorded in deed records in 1868. In July 1868, Charles Crocker made conveyances to S. Barclay, John Piper, William H. Potter, and O.C. Madden in Washoe County, Nevada, recorded in deed records. Charles Crocker made several conveyances in Washoe County, Nevada, including ones to Peter Zenovich, George Zenovich, Mrs. M.A. Pine, T.R. Hughes, and Joseph Leonard, recorded between 1871 and 1873. In 1873, Charles Crocker made conveyances in Washoe County, Nevada to various individuals, including S.M. Jamison, W.R. Chamberlain, W.S. Bender, C.S. Martin, and E.C. McKenney, recorded between 1875 and 1881. In book 9, page 296, Charles Crocker conveyed property to Josephine E. McCutchen in Washoe County. Another conveyance involved the Southern Pacific Transportation Company, Lincoln Management Company, Donald L. Carano, and Raymond J. Poncia, Jr. recorded in book 2806, page 950 in 1988. The Southern Pacific Transportation Company made conveyances to Western Pacific Development Corporation, Zante Inc., and Frank F. Knafel in Nevada in 1988 and 1989. The Southern Pacific Transportation Company made conveyances to various entities in Nevada in 1989 and 1990, including George E. Croom, Jr., Sharon M. Croom, and the Redevelopment Agency of the City of Reno. SEC. 4. LIMITATIONS ON VALIDATION OF CONVEYANCES. The Act does not reduce the right-of-way width for Southern Pacific Transportation Company's main tracks, does not validate adverse possession rights, and does not affect existing access rights. The United States reserves federally owned minerals. The United States reserves federally owned minerals in land conveyed under this Act, allowing entry and utilization of the surface for mineral removal. Reserved minerals are withdrawn from mining, mineral leasing, and geothermal leasing laws.
